Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1253739
PI: Salac

The objective of this award, co-funded by the Biomaterials Program in Division of Materials Research, is to perform in-silico and in-vitro investigations of single and multicomponent vesicles in fluid flow and during exposure to electric fields. Vesicles exposed to the combined effects of fluid flow and electric fields have shown a wide and varied set of behaviors. Exposure to electric fields have induced vesicle shapes not normally accessible. Weak electric fields have induced lipid flow patterns in the membranes of multicomponent vesicles. As the electric field strength is increased pores begin to form in the vesicle membrane. This allows foreign substance to either enter or leave the vesicle. Vesicles exposed to strong electric fields have been shown to burst. It is unknown how exposure to combined fluid and electric effects will influence vesicle behavior. The proposed work will answer the following specific biological questions: 1) How does the combined effects of fluid flow and electric fields influence the dynamics of vesicles and lipids in the vesicle membranes? 2) Under what conditions will electroporation occur and what is the lifespan of these pores?


If successful the knowledge gained will greatly advance the development of vesicle based biotechnologies, such as directed drug delivery mechanisms and small-scale bio-reactors. The techniques used to investigate vesicle electrohydrodynamics are also applicable to other systems such as red blood cells and animal locomotion. The PI is also committed to incorporating techniques and results from this research into the engineering curriculum at the University at Buffalo SUNY. The PI will also use this research to attract underrepresented groups to pursue an engineering education.

Institution.Name: SUNY at Buffalo
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK, THE

POR.DRECONTENT:
Vesicles exposed to the combined effects of fluid flow and electric fields have shown a wide and varied set of behaviors. Exposure to electric fields have induced vesicle shape deformations while multicomponent vesicles have shown electric field induced membrane flow patterns. This research combined novel numerical methods with high performance computing to investigate the three-dimensional dynamics of vesicles in a wide variety of flow conditions and in the presence of electric fields. The research showed how flow conditions, material properties, and external fields interact to determine the dynamics of vesicles and was the first investigation of three-dimensional vesicle electrohydrodynamics of arbitrary vesicles with no restrictions on membrane dynamics. It also discovered novel dynamics of multi-component vesicles in shear flow, which have not yet been observed. This work was the first to demonstrate that due to the interplay between bending energy and shear flow forces the membrane of a multi-component vesicle may resist the typical tank-treading behavior when exposed to shear flows and the growth rates of multicomponent membrane domains in the presense of thermal noise.

Three PhD students, two of which are underrepresented minorities or female, along with three MS students, one of which was an underrepresented minority, were trained in numerical methods, high performance computing, programming, microfluidic device fabrication, and soft-matter electrohydrodynamics. This work work resulted in two PhD dissertations and two MS thesis. Additionally, the PI has worked with three high school students, with work ranging from basic programming to experimental development. The research resulted in nine publications and twenty-one conference presentations, many of which were given by students. A new graduate level course on moving interfaces and multiphase flow has also been developed and multiple conference sessions related to this work have also been organized.


Last Modified: 10/27/2019
Modified by: David Salac

    E. Kolahdouz and D. Salac
    David Salac
    Vesicle POP Transition
  • Tank-treading dynamics of a multicomponent vesicle with varying bending rigidity in the presence of shear flow.
    P. Gera and D. Salac
    Copyrighted
    David Salac
    Multicomponent Tank Treading

Exposure to electric fields have induced vesicle shape deformations while multicomponent vesicles have shown electric field induced membrane flow patterns. This research combined novel numerical methods with high performance computing to investigate the three-dimensional dynamics of vesicles in a wide variety of flow conditions and in the presence of electric fields. It also discovered novel dynamics of multi-component vesicles in shear flow, which have not yet been observed. This work was the first to demonstrate that due to the interplay between bending energy and shear flow forces the membrane of a multi-component vesicle may resist the typical tank-treading behavior when exposed to shear flows and the growth rates of multicomponent membrane domains in the presense of thermal noise. Three PhD students, two of which are underrepresented minorities or female, along with three MS students, one of which was an underrepresented minority, were trained in numerical methods, high performance computing, programming, microfluidic device fabrication, and soft-matter electrohydrodynamics.
